title: Closure of local paper signals end of independent print media in Goldfields
text:
The Esperance Weekender has published its final edition and joined a growing number of regional publications shutting their doors.

The South Coast paper is the last independent masthead to leave the Goldfields and one of only a handful left in regional Western Australia.

The Weekender, which announced its closure in this week's edition, was started by a group of local benefactors who saw a need for a local newspaper after the town’s only weekly paper, The Esperance Express, ceased operating during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Weekender editor Geoff Vivian, who joined the paper in 2023, said the budget had always been marginal and that shareholders saw the venture as more of a "social enterprise".

"There was only one of those four years where it managed to pay for all of its bills, and it wasn't last financial year," he said.

Loading...

Media diversity shrinking

The closure of the Esperance Weekender coincides with the 130th birthday of the Seven West Media-owned Kalgoorlie Miner, which is the last remaining print publication in the region.

In WA, the majority of regional newspapers are owned by Seven West Media, which has 19 regional mastheads across the state.

Earlier this year, concerns were raised about media diversity due to the proposed merger between Seven West Media and Southern Cross Media.

Western Australia's only regional daily newspaper, the Kalgoorlie Miner, has celebrated its 130th anniversary. (ABC Goldfields: Jarrod Lucas)

Mr Vivian said the decline in regional publications and the concentration of ownership were points of concern.

"Democracy and newspapers grew up together over about the past 400 years in our culture," he said.

"It worries me that there’s almost only one owner of newspapers in WA — it certainly owns more than nine out of 10 of all newspapers in WA, as well as the national TV network."

Local and Independent News Association (LINA) executive director Claire Stuchbery said the decline of independent news media was about revenue streams.

"We're seeing more and more of that advertising dollar moving to the social platforms, and that loss has really impacted business models, "she said.

"Similarly, we're seeing people not necessarily wanting to pay for news."

Ms Stuchbery said smaller, independent newsrooms could look to diversify their revenue streams.

"That might be in helping to organise community events, that might be in reader contributions in other formats," she said.

"So looking at a really broad array of revenue streams that are potential ways that local newsrooms can make their work more sustainable."

Claire Stuchberry works for LINA, a not-for-profit supporting local and independent media. (Supplied: LINA)

Ms Stuchbery said news content was also increasingly syndicated from metropolitan newsrooms.

She said international, national and statewide news remained important, but people needed to know what was going on where they lived and worked.

"A lot of that content is being reported from Sydney, which means that it's further away from issues that are really valid to local communities," Ms Stuchbery said.

She said that not only affected the diversity of stories for local communities, but also the stories from the regions that could have a broader reach.

History of news in the Goldfields

The Goldfields' first newspaper, the Coolgardie Miner, was published in 1894.

Kalgoorlie-Boulder historian Tim Moore said there had been more than 60 mastheads in the Goldfields during the early part of the 20th century.

Tim Moore says several printing presses were sent to the region during the gold rush. (ABC Goldfields: Katrina Tap)

Mr Moore said there were not only newspapers for each town, but also for each cultural group.

"There was a newspaper here out of Coolgardie called the Othersider, and that was a newspaper aimed at all the people from the eastern states who came to Kalgoorlie-Boulder and Coolgardie," he said.

"What we had at the beginning of last century to what we have now, there's a huge gulf … print media still exists, but really it's localised print media."

The closure of the Esperance Weekender was announced in its final edition. (ABC Goldfields: Andrew Williams)

Mr Moore said the decline in diverse media sources could also affect the work of historians, who may have to rely more heavily on conducting interviews to understand historic events.

"It sort of makes our job only a bit more difficult because we've got a smaller pool of evidence on which to make conclusions," he said.

title: Why Liz Stringer 'doesn't have many s***s left to give'
text:
Australian singer-songwriter Liz Stringer has spent decades navigating the music industry's twists and turns, learning not just its mechanics but which battles are worth her energy, and which aren't.

"I'm in my 40s now and I don't have a lot of shits left to give about what people think about me," she says.

"I just don't have the energy for it. All the energy has to go into making art now."

Celebrate Ausmusic Month on Double J Tune in for all Australian Live At The Wireless sets, Take 5 interviews, Classic Albums and lots of great Australian music.

Balancing creativity with the relentless demands of the industry is a battle even in the best of times. Recent professional changes have made prioritising creativity an even trickier proposition.

"I found myself, about a year ago, self-managed again. Anyone who's self-managed knows it's so much work and my creative process has suffered as a result," she says.

"I've only just started to write songs again after a quite a long period of not writing songs. That's the necessity of having to wear a million hats when you're working in the creative industries."

Sometimes instinct trumps convenience.

After recording her latest album, The Second High, in London, Stringer felt compelled to stay: a decision that tested her resilience but reignited her creative spark.

"I was really inspired being there," Stringer says.

London, she says, is both punishing and electrifying.

"Everyone who's been there is probably aware that it's a pretty brutal city in a lot of ways. It's incredibly expensive, it's massive, it's super busy all the time. It's incredibly stressful.

"It's also an incredibly exciting and inspiring place to be.

"It's been a challenge for me, and it's really tested my faith in my own ability as an artist and my dedication to art, because it hasn't been an easy transition at all. But I also don't regret it for a second."

A sense of purpose

Now back from London for a spell, she's deep in the throes of a 17-date Australian tour. One driven by more than music.

Stringer has partnered with local housing organisations in every stop to raise money and remind people of the struggles society's most vulnerable are facing.

"The way that we've managed to start working with all these charities all over Australia has given it such a sense of purpose," she says.

Liz Stringer announces mega 17-date Australian tour One of the country's most powerful songwriters willt ake her exceptional new album on the road.

She played a fundraiser for Melbourne's Wombat Housing Services a few years ago and saw this tour as an opportunity to support organisations making a difference in helping society's most vulnerable.

"The pandemic was a great leveller, in a sense, because we were all affected by the same thing. But obviously people who were already in precarious positions were in even more precarious positions," Stringer says.

Organisations like Orange Sky and Signal Flare in Brisbane, Will2Live in Sydney, Hutt St Centre in Adelaide and the Katherine Women's Crisis Centre will be beneficiaries of not just money but also awareness from the shows.

"Look, I don't have a massive profile, but even if we raise a few grand for each of these organisations — because they're working on the smell of an oily rag — it will make a difference," Stringer says.

She says she wants to support people and organisations that are doing it tough.

But she also wants to raise awareness in the wider community about the issues.

"Really bring it back into the consciousness," she says.

For Stringer's dedicated Australian fans, the run of shows presents a long-overdue opportunity to connect with the singer-songwriter.

It's also a chance for Stringer and her band to re-establish their own magical connection.

"This is the biggest tour I've done since before the pandemic. I used to do tours this size a lot," she says.

"One of the great frustrations of the last few years is not being able to string a bunch of shows together and become really match fit as a band.

"That was always the real highlight of that sort of touring for me. So, I'm looking forward to that, doing 13 or 14 band shows [and] honing our sound together. I think that's gonna be so fun."

The great confidence balancing act

While she's been a consummate live performer from the jump, Stringer acknowledges that she's recently interrogated her relationship with live shows.

Those who haven't seen her for a while will likely experience her as a more comfortable and perhaps more generous performer.

Loading Instagram content

"I've always really liked performing live, but I think when I was younger it was sort of like, 'Just get on and play everything really quickly and get off as quick as possible,'" she says.

"Now I integrate who I am a bit more into my live shows. There's just a much more solid foundation to the way that I write, and the way that I am as an artist."

Having a little more pluck and courage is undoubtedly a positive thing. But it's equally important to keep it somewhat in check.

Loading Instagram content

"You've gotta try and maintain a sense of confidence, but not overconfidence," Stringer says.

"I think it's easy to have smoke blown up your arse in this industry as well, and that's as dangerous as the rejection.

"It's a challenge for most people to maintain the sort of retaining walls of self-confidence."

Confidence can be a limited resource, especially in an industry that loves to judge and doesn't always consider fairness a key metric.

"I've weathered a lot of years in an industry that is pretty brutal," Stringer considers.

"However much I have gotten better at protecting myself, artists are necessarily quite sensitive people.

"It's been difficult to repel all the rejection and that sort of stuff over the years. In that sense, I sort of feel a little bit browbeaten.

"On the other hand, my sense of who I am as an artist and my understanding of my own ability and what I'm capable of is just so much better developed than it was."

Not having many shits left to give has allowed her to direct energy and confidence into the things that really matter.

"There's benefits to a bit of age under your belt, I think," Stringer says.

"You realise the time and energy that's wasted on stuff that used to cause me so much anxiety and angst as a younger person.

"That's just the process of getting older and repeating patterns and being in situations again and again — you just learn how to do it."

Growth over glory

For Stringer, it's important to channel any time and energy she has into creating art that she's proud of.

"I think what's really important to me now, which wasn't so important earlier on, is that I'm pushing myself creatively every time I make an album," she says.

"As a musician, I've always had a certain amount of natural ability that comes from my family — my dad's the same. I feel like early on I just cruised on that and was just like 'Oh, I can do this' and I'll just sort of make the same record four times.

"But now it's really important for me to continue to put myself out of my comfort zone and get better and learn more. That's a process that never ends.

"I want to be able to feel like I've learned something from a record now, which didn't occur to me earlier on."

Liz Stringer is on tour around Australia right now. Get all the information here.

title: 'Untouched' or 'Dark Horse': The songs behind today's AFLW semifinal
text:
Before every game this year, the Carlton players get together and sing Untouched by Australian duo The Veronicas.

"Before the game, we were a bit silly," Erone Fitzpatrick told ABC Sport after the Blues' dominant 41-point elimination final win against West Coast last weekend.

"We have Ciara Fitzgerald, she gets in the middle of everybody and we just all dance to 'Untouched'.

"We play our best football when we're a bit silly and just joy and celebration really is what we're chasing this year — and I think you can see that with the way we're playing.

"I think that's the vibe that you can see on the field too, just everybody gets around each other and we're silly, but we're having fun at the same time."

Carlton are playing in finals for the first time since 2020. (Getty: James Worsfold/AFL Photos)

Carlton is playing finals for the first time since 2020 this year and will go into Saturday's semifinal against Hawthorn as the favourites.

Many have credited younger players such as Sophie McKay, Poppy Scholz and Lila Keck as giving the side that has struggled in recent seasons with a new energy.

In the opposing colours, Hawthorn players have been using the song Dark Horse by Katy Perry as one of their songs this year.

Midfielder Eliza West said it was emblematic of how they felt like underdogs despite achieving a top-four finish.

"Just from how our season panned out, and we've had to grind out some tough games. We're still feeling like we're the underdogs and we still have a point to prove," West said.

The 'tough' time that led to West playing finals with Hawthorn Eliza West is leading the Hawks on a finals charge in the AFLW, but it comes after a 'disheartening' call at the Demons.

The Hawks were second on the ladder heading into the final home-and-away game, but finished fourth after going down to minor premiers by 49 points.

This meant they had to face the Kangaroos again in the first week of finals, this time going down by 39 points.

They now face another straight-sets finals exit — after finishing in the top four last year but crashing out with back-to-back losses — after a season marred by injury.

Key players Lucy Wales, Emily Bates, Aileen Gilroy, Jasmine Fleming, Ainslie Kemp, Najwa Allen, Bridie Hipwell, and Jenna Richardson have all missed significant portions of the season through injury.

The side will regain captain Bates for the do-or-die clash with Carlton, while second-year players Hayley McLaughlin and Sophie Butterworth come in to replace injured pair Emily Everist (concussion) and Kaitlyn Ashmore (calf).

Hawthorn have struggled with significant injuries this season. (Getty Images: AFL Photos/Michael Willson)

Despite the injury setbacks, West said there was a lot of confidence within the group — and Perry was helping to get their energy up before the game.

"We've actually got a few songs that we play beforehand at different points. But I think Aine (McDonagh) and Casey (Sherriff) are the controllers of that," West said.

"The girls love to sing and dance before the game, it gives them energy going in … some of the girls, like Aine, she will do it and then go out and kick three goals."

West laughed that some of the older players, like herself and Tilly Lucas-Rodd, prefer to try to conserve their energy and warm their bodies up by throwing the ball around instead, but the song was good to get all the players into the same spirit.

Which for them is being the 'dark horse' of this finals series.

Hawthorn hosts Carlton for the semifinal clash at Princes Park on Saturday night.

title: Couple who bought unit six weeks ago say they couldn't afford it now
text:
Serena and Miffy were thrilled to crack the Brisbane property market in their early 20s — but just six weeks on, their unit has soared in value and they say they wouldn't be able to afford it now.

The couple bought their one-bedroom unit in Brisbane's affluent, leafy suburb of New Farm using the federal government's 5 per cent deposit scheme.

Loading...

"Without the scheme it would have been tight for us, it's definitely given us a leg up," 24-year-old Serena said.

Under the government's scheme, first home buyers across all income levels can now secure a property with just a 5 per cent deposit and avoid paying costly lenders mortgage insurance (LMI).

The scheme was previously limited to singles earning under $125,000 and couples with a combined income below $200,000, but the government has now lifted those income caps.

The scheme has drawn mixed public reactions, and the couple said the process remained "stressful," with crowded inspections and rising prices adding to the pressure.

The couple say they’ve heard criticism of the scheme, even though it helped them. (ABC News: Shari Hams)

Miffy, 23, said inspecting properties alongside experienced investors was intense.

"You'd be shuffling around all these people, trying to get a glimpse of the bathroom, that was awful, and everyone feels like your competitor."

" It feels very isolating going to properties when everyone's in a different demographic to you. "

Despite only being purchased several weeks ago, their unit has already grown in value. (ABC News: Shari Hams)

In just a few weeks, the value of their unit has already climbed by an estimated $50,000, according to property experts.

The couple said the higher price point would likely put it out of reach if they were buying now.

Are 5pc deposits pushing up prices? Young Australians say a 5 per cent deposit helps, but does not cure all housing ills.

They said they felt sympathetic for people still trying to break into the market.

"The growth is running away from everyone — the best time to buy property is always yesterday," Miffy said.

"It's already moved so much in just six weeks, and it keeps climbing."

While the scheme has helped them, they are uncertain whether it offers a long-term solution to the housing affordability crisis.

A million-dollar unit sale

A two-bedroom brick walk-up unit on Moreton Street in New Farm has just sold for a little over $1 million — a "bittersweet" milestone, according to the real estate agent.

Rissman Property's Ben Lobie said it's the first time his agency has seen a "basic unit" of this kind — the sort typically built in the 1970s and 80s with no lift, amenities or large balcony — break the million-dollar mark.

Loading...

"It's bittersweet as we've got owners on one side who are very excited as obviously they are starting to make money but then we've got a lot of people who are trying to buy one," he said.

Specialising in New Farm, Mr Lobie said strong demand for units in the area is pushing prices higher.

This New Farm unit sold for $1,001,000 at the start of October. (Supplied: realestate.com)

"We have around 2,000 two-bedroom units in New Farm, and at the moment there are only three or four on the market," he said.

“Because so few are available and even fewer sell, prices normally fluctuate a bit — one might rise while another drops — but that just isn’t happening right now.”

Loading...

He estimated the same property would have sold for around $700,000 this time last year.

"It's not going to go backwards," he said.

One in 10 homes bought using government incentive in October About one in 10 homes sold last month were bought by Australians using Labor's expanded 5 per cent deposit scheme to enter the market for the first time.

Property expert Tim Graham echoed the sentiment.

"If we look at New Farm, where these units were purchased, we're seeing an 11 per cent growth in units, compared with just 8 per cent for houses, it's a trend we've been reporting on for some time," he said.

However, Mr Graham noted the million-dollar Moreton street sale was about $100,000 above his own valuation, driven by several factors.

“We’re seeing higher rental yields and stronger rental growth in unit markets, with units competing closely in terms of capital growth,” he said.

Loading...

Buyers opt for units

A new Domain report showed Australian buyers increasingly traded freestanding houses for more affordable townhouses and units as housing prices rose.

The analysis compared buyer searches over the past year with actual listing prices, highlighting the shift toward units.

"We've been reporting on this trend for over 18 months now, a trend that's sweeping the nation that units are going toe to toe on capital growth across the nation," Mr Graham said.

" It used to be the poor cousin to houses. "

Loading...

He said a growing range of people are choosing this type of living, with the trend spreading to other capital cities and even smaller markets like Darwin and Hobart.

"Whether it's down-sizers, right-sizers, lifestyle buyers, or many migrants accustomed to unit living, it's a trend we expect to continue," he said.

"The biggest story around Brisbane is absolutely undersupply, they simply cannot build or keep up with the demand that the city needs."

Mr Lobie says a strong demand for units is pushing prices higher. (ABC News: Shari Hams)

Mr Lobie said while it's a strong market for sellers, the pressure to buy is increasing.

"People assume we're all thrilled about this … some of my clients are, but some aren't," he said.

"Half of our office can't afford these units anymore. Our job is to sell for the best price, but we've got colleagues watching each sale over the past month, and they're frustrated."

title: Nearly half of Qld homebirth program participants gave birth in hospital
text:
A "small" number of women who were ineligible for Queensland's first publicly funded homebirth program decided to freebirth, a leaked report into the first year of the program has revealed.

The report, obtained by the ABC, has recommended doctors and midwives work with women who are "risked out of the program" to develop an individual plan to reduce the dangers of freebirthing.

A freebirth is when a woman decides to give birth without assistance from a registered health professional.

The practice is facing growing scrutiny after publicity surrounding deaths of mothers and babies.

'Sovereign birthkeepers' putting lives at risk They check the baby's position and listen to the heartbeat, but they aren't qualified midwives. Parents say a "dangerous" new breed of birth worker has emerged to fill the gap for women wanting to birth outside hospital.

Peak medical and midwifery groups have called for health ministers across the country to pass laws so that only registered midwives and doctors can manage labour and childbirth, following the deaths.

The 12-month evaluation report of a publicly funded homebirth program run on the Sunshine Coast said a "small number of women" who were ineligible for the program due to clinical risk factors, "chose to freebirth".

"This is an undesirable and potentially unsafe outcome," the report said.

"Midwives reported limitations related to professional indemnity when providing care outside Queensland Health guidelines.

" A collaborative, inter-professional model involving midwives, obstetricians, and women may help develop individualised care plans for women with moderate risk factors, reducing the likelihood of unsupervised births. "

Queensland was one of the last states to announce a publicly funded homebirth service in late 2023, giving eligible women the option to birth in the comfort of their own homes, supported by trained midwives.

Just over half of participants birthed at home, report finds

The project, launched in July 2024 at the Sunshine Coast University Hospital (SCUH), aimed to expand maternity care options by offering a homebirth service to eligible women with low-risk pregnancies.

Loading...

Earlier this year, the ABC asked Sunshine Coast Health (SCH) how many women participating in the program ended up giving birth in hospital, but a spokeswoman declined to provide the figure, saying "there was not enough data to protect patient confidentiality".

"With such a limited sample size, it's not possible to draw reliable correlations or meaningful conclusions without risking misinterpretation," she said.

The report into the first year of the program shows just over half of women enrolled ended up giving birth at home.

35 women who had been enrolled in the homebirth program were transferred to hospital care for a range of reasons. (ABC News: Mark Leonardi)

According to the report, 74 women enrolled in the service between July 2024 and 30 June 2025, with 39 women giving birth at home.

Paramedics were called to 14 of the homebirths and assisted in 10 of them.

The remaining 35 women enrolled in the program were transferred to hospital care for a range of reasons including medical treatment indicated, monitoring required and change of mind.

One of those women had a caesarean birth after being transferred to hospital during labour.

Sunshine Coast Health says it was proud to have helped local families who were eligible to participate in the homebirth program. (ABC News: Lucas Hill)

SCH said a similar interstate service recorded 20 homebirths in its first year.

"We're very proud of what we've achieved for local families," a spokeswoman said.

"Choosing where to give birth is a deeply personal decision, and some women decide to change their plans as their due date approaches or even during labour.

"This can happen for many reasons, such as a desire for pain relief or the need for a clinical transfer to keep both mother and baby safe."

'Any birth could face challenges'

Obstetrician Gino Pecoraro said the high number of low-risk women in the Queensland program who were transferred to hospital care clearly illustrated that any birth could suddenly face challenges.

"If nearly half of all women allocated to the study needed transfer, how does this provide value for the taxpayer?" Dr Pecoraro said.

Dr Gino Pecoraro says the decision for women to freebirth suggests hospitals need to become more welcoming for birthing. (AAP: Russell Freeman)

"What is the actual dollar cost for each woman looked after and each baby delivered? I think there's a whole heap of unanswered questions that I'd like to know before the program is expanded."

Dr Pecoraro, president of the National Association of Specialist Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, said the decision for women to freebirth showed hospitals needed to become "more welcoming" for birthing women.

What to know about home births There's been an increase in home births in recent years but they're not accessible to all, and they're not considered suitable for every pregnancy.

"I think it tells us that there is something wrong with the current maternity system if we've got people who are prepared to listen to influencers and people with no training over the advice from people that have studied for 20 years," he said.

"What are we doing wrong when all of a sudden women are decrying the safety of having a baby in hospital and could we use this money better to make the hospital more homelike?"

Broader access wanted for program

Under existing criteria of Queensland's publicly funded home birth program, only women living within a 30-minute radius of Sunshine Coast University Hospital are eligible.

While that parameter was established in line with best practice evidence, the report noted patient feedback "strongly supports" broader access, "warranting further exploration of safe and sustainable options for program expansion".

According to the report, 74 women enrolled in the service between July 2024 and 30 June 2025, with 39 women giving birth at home. (ABC News: Briana Shepherd)

It recommended a review of the eligibility criteria for "acceptable residence distance from the hospital".

Sunshine Coast Health said it acknowledged the recommendations in the report and was reviewing them to "ensure any future improvements to the home birth program continue to prioritise the safety of mothers and babies".

"Any changes to eligibility criteria, including distance-from-hospital requirements, will be carefully considered in consultation with clinical experts and maternity stakeholders," the spokeswoman said.

The report said demand for homebirths in Queensland has been increasing, with rates rising from 0.1 per cent to 0.5 per cent of all births between 2011 and 2021.

"Expanding maternity services to include publicly funded homebirths as an option offers both clinical and economic benefits," the report said.

Only women living within a 30-minute radius of Sunshine Coast University Hospital are eligible under the current program's guidelines. (ABC News: Lucas Hill)

"Shifting a portion of low-risk births to a homebirth model could reduce the financial burden on Queensland's public healthcare system, as perinatal care is a major contributor to hospital costs."

The report recommended securing long-term investment of publicly funded homebirth as part of the maternity system and ensure it is embedded in service agreements.

It estimated that if five per cent of public hospital births in Queensland were planned as home births, the system could save about $11 million per year, or more than $5,500 per low-risk pregnancy.

title: Trump seeks probe of Epstein ties to former US president Bill Clinton
text:
President Donald Trump says he will ask the Department of Justice to investigate Jeffrey Epstein's links to US bank JPMorgan and prominent Democrats, including former president Bill Clinton.

The request comes two days after a congressional committee released thousands of documents that raised new questions about Mr Trump's relationship with the late convicted sex offender.

It marks the latest in a series of demands by Mr Trump for federal law enforcement to pursue his perceived political enemies.

The justice department did not immediately respond to a request for comment. (Reuters: Elizabeth Frantz)

The Epstein scandal has been a political thorn in Mr Trump's side for months, partly because he amplified conspiracy theories about Epstein to his own supporters.

Many Trump voters believe the government has covered up Epstein's ties to powerful figures and obscured details surrounding his death by suicide in a Manhattan jail in 2019.

Along with Mr Clinton, who socialised with Epstein in the early 2000s, Mr Trump said he had asked the Justice Department to investigate former treasury secretary Larry Summers, and Reid Hoffman, the LinkedIn founder who is also a prominent Democratic donor.

All three men were mentioned in the 20,000 Epstein-related documents released by the House Oversight Committee on Wednesday.

Bill Clinton said he cut ties with Jeffrey Epstein once sexual assault allegations emerged against him. (Reuters: Lucy Nicholson)

"Epstein was a Democrat, and he is the Democrat's [sic] problem, not the Republican's [sic] problem!" Mr Trump wrote on social media.

" They all know about him, don't waste your time with Trump. I have a Country to run! "

Attorney General Pam Bondi says the department will pursue the Epstein case with urgency.

Breaking down the newly released Epstein emails Donald Trump's relationship with Jeffrey Epstein is pushed back into the spotlight after he was named in several years-old emails unearthed by a congressional committee investigation.

The justice department did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

A JPMorgan spokesperson said in an emailed statement: "We regret any association we had with the man, but did not help him commit his heinous acts."

Mr Clinton and Mr Summers did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

Mr Hoffman could not be immediately reached for comment.

Trump faces continued pressure over Epstein

Mr Trump and Epstein were friends during the 1990s and the 2000s, but Mr Trump says he broke off ties before Epstein pleaded guilty in 2008 to charges of soliciting a minor for prostitution.

Mr Trump has consistently denied knowing about the late financier's abuse and sex trafficking of underage girls.

Still, some of Mr Trump's most ardent supporters have accused his administration of a cover-up.

Jeffrey Epstein and Donald Trump were friends during the 1990s and the 2000s. (Getty Images: Davidoff Studios)

Mr Trump, who frequently engages with reporters, has declined to take questions over the past several days as new revelations about Epstein have become public.

The Republican-controlled House of Representatives is expected to vote next week on legislation that would force the Department of Justice to release all of the material it holds on Epstein, who was facing federal charges of sex trafficking minors at the time of his suicide.

The measure is expected to pass, even after House Speaker Mike Johnson repeatedly tried to block the vote.

An image of US President Donald Trump alongside Jeffrey Epstein was projected onto Windsor castle, during his UK tour in September. (Reuters: Phil Noble)

It would also require the Senate to pass similar legislation and Mr Trump's approval to compel the justice department to act.

Just four in 10 Republicans in an October Reuters/Ipsos poll said they approved of Mr Trump's handling of the Epstein files, well below the nine in 10 who approved of his overall performance in the White House.

Trump distraction tactics

Mr Trump has harnessed the justice department to target other political opponents, some of whom now face criminal charges that outside experts have described as politically motivated.

"Trump is clearly desperately trying to distract from his own presence in the Epstein emails," said a former Department of Justice lawyer, Alan Rozenshtein.

What we learned from Epstein's emails A trove of Jeffrey Epstein emails released this week reveals his preoccupation with US President Donald Trump in the years before Epstein's death.

"It's outrageously inappropriate for the president to be giving orders to the Department of Justice to investigate individual United States citizens," said a former federal prosecutor, Patrick J. Cotter.

"That is not how it's supposed to work."

On Friday, Mr Trump said he knew "nothing" about an email from Jeffrey Epstein suggesting he knew about the disgraced financier's sexual abuse.

"I know nothing about that. They would have announced that a long time ago," Mr Trump told reporters aboard Air Force One when asked what Epstein meant in a 2019 email saying "of course he knew about the girls".

JPMorgan paid $US290 million ($443 million) in 2023 to some of Epstein's victims to settle accusations that it had turned a blind eye to his sex trafficking.

Jeffrey Epstein victims reach $430 million settlement with JPMorgan Chase bank JPMorgan Chase has agreed to pay about $430 million to settle a lawsuit by Jeffrey Epstein's victims who had accused the bank of being the financial conduit that allowed him to continue operating a sex trafficking operation.

The deal followed embarrassing disclosures that JPMorgan ignored internal warnings and overlooked red flags about Epstein, who was a client of the bank between 1998 and 2013.

The bank did not admit wrongdoing in the settlement.

No credible evidence has surfaced that Mr Clinton, Mr Summers or Mr Hoffman were involved in Epstein's sex trafficking.

All have previously denied wrongdoing and have expressed regret about their relationships with him.

Former US Treasury secretary Larry Summers accepted philanthropic gifts from Epstein while serving as president of Harvard University. (Supplied: Larry Summers)

Mr Clinton flew on Epstein's private jet several times before the financier's 2008 conviction, while Mr Summers accepted philanthropic gifts from Epstein while serving as president of Harvard University.

Mr Hoffman has acknowledged meeting with Epstein multiple times in professional situations.

Before his 2008 conviction, Epstein worked and socialised with a long list of well-known figures, including the UK's former Prince Andrew, who was stripped of his royal title due in part to his association with Epstein.

Reuters/ AFP

title: Melbourne Demons vs Adelaide Crows AFLW Finals LIVE: Dees, Crows battle at Ikon Park as semi-finals begin
text:
Coach Matthew Clarke is certain Adelaide are peaking at the right time, but remains wary of an injury-hit Melbourne in their AFLW semi-final.

The Crows travel to Melbourne for Saturday afternoon’s sudden-death encounter buoyed by their 44-point drubbing of St Kilda in an elimination final.

Caitlin Gould and Niamh Kelly of the Crows (right) celebrate a goal in their elimination final win. Credit: AFL Photos via Getty Images

“It was arguably our strongest performance for the season,” Clarke told reporters on Friday at Adelaide airport.

“We felt as though throughout the year we’ve had patches, we have played pretty good footy, but perhaps been inconsistent.

“So to bring our best game towards the back-end, and obviously in the finals, that’s really pleasing.

“You hope to play your best footy at the back-end and you probably should, given that you’re starting to work together as a unit more consistently.”

Clarke has named an unchanged side for the Ikon Park fixture but the Demons, who slipped to a 13-point qualifying loss to Brisbane, made two alterations.

Loading

Star goalkicker Eden Zanker (concussion) will miss and Jemma Rigoni has been dropped, with Sinead Goldrick and Laela Ebert summoned.

“Obviously for them, losing Zanker probably hurt them last week within the game,” Clarke said.

“But they″⁣ve had the whole week to prepare and structure up and they’ve got multiple aerial threats ahead of the ball, even without her.

“That is a significant out for them, but it’s part of footy, you’ve got to be able to manage some adversity.

“We’ve been watching the way they’ve gone about it. They have had a great year and even last week, a lot of the metrics say they should have won that game.

“They’re really good around the contest ... they move the ball really efficiently into their front half.

“And then, like most teams, they support defensively really strongly as well.”

An Adelaide loss will finish the tenure of dual premiership coach Clarke, who is stepping down at season’s end.

“The question has come up a lot but the answer has been pretty similar,” he said.

“AFLW is a really short season and so your focus becomes really intense in terms of the next game.

“And then you throw in the fact that you get to finals, all that other stuff is really peripheral. It’s not even a factor.

“It’s really just let’s go, let’s see if we can win a game.”

AAP

title: International friendly LIVE: Socceroos take next step on road to 2026 World Cup
text:
Here’s the team Tony Popovic has selected:

So there’s three debutants: goalkeeper Patrick Beach, the current standout in his position in the A-League, defender Kai Trewin, his teammate at Melbourne City, and midfielder Paul Okon-Engstler, the son of Socceroos assistant coach Paul Okon who recently moved to Sydney FC and has started the season pretty well.

Okon-Engstler is just 20, was born in Belgium (his father was playing for K.V. Oostende at the time) and came through the youth academies of Club Brugge and Benfica. Clearly, he has been identified as a star of the future for Australia - but can he play a role now, or at the World Cup? This is a great test for him.

Elsewhere, Craig Goodwin also starts for the first time since March in what appears to be the left wing-back role - interesting - with Nestory Irankunda, Mohamed Toure and Connor Metcalfe up front, and Aiden O’Neill in midfield next to Okon-Engstler.

Milos Degenek has the captain’s armband, while Nick D’Agostino and Kye Rowles are not in the squad, and Deni Juric left camp early after sustaining an injury, which means Al Hassan Toure is a really high chance to also debut off the bench.

title: ‘Everyone met him with open arms’: McGrath on the return of Essendon prodigal son Merrett
text:
Loading McGrath’s name is at the top of the list of likely successors to Merrett as Essendon captain, should the club make the change. McGrath said it was too early to talk about the captaincy, but also wouldn’t rule out taking on the role if it becomes available. “It’s something I haven’t really put any thought to yet,” McGrath said. “We’ve had our break, and I got married a couple of weeks ago, so footy has been on the backburner a little bit.

“Those conversations will happen over the next few months. We’ll sit down with the club and figure out the next way forward, and it will be what it will be.” McGrath, 27, was among the Essendon leaders – including the likes of Nic Martin and Mason Redman – to speak out in September about Merrett wanting out. McGrath told Seven at the time that there was “disappointment, a little bit of anger and sadness” about Merrett wanting out. McGrath has experienced plenty of turbulence as a Bomber, but he’s also learnt what it takes to become a leader. Zach Merrett and McGrath share a laugh back in April. Credit: AFL Photos “If you have been in the system for a while, you’ve seen a lot, and seen the good and the bad that footy throws up,” McGrath said.

“I’ve been lucky enough to have so many good leaders above me for my whole career with Dyson [Heppell] and Zach currently. You learn bits and pieces from those guys. “Everyone my age is a leader at the footy club – we’ve got some great middle-aged sort of guys, but they seem a bit older with how young our playing list is at the moment. “Guys like Kyle Langford, Mason Redman and Nic Martin are great young, emerging leaders. Sam Durham as well. “It doesn’t really feel like a big responsibility because we share the load so well. “It’s something that comes a little bit naturally to me, like connecting with the guys, and I enjoy being around my teammates, but we will see where it all lands.”

A chance meeting for Charlie Superstar Swans recruit Charlie Curnow admits he’s still adjusting to life in the harbour city, away from Carlton and his former teammates. And he looked shocked when he took some breakfast out to a car at the McHappy Day event in Tullamarine on Saturday morning, only to find it was former Blues skipper Marc Murphy waiting patiently. For his part, Murphy looked just as shocked – especially when two TV cameras took in the transaction. Sydney star Charlie Curnow tests out a burger on McHappy Day on Saturday. Credit: Eddie Jim “I think he was just using young Maxy [Murphy’s son] as an excuse to come past Maccas,” Curnow said with a wide smile.

“I was surprised to see him but I always see him around Carlton North near the cafes.” Both Curnow’s friendship groups lit up this week when the AFL announced the Blues would travel to Sydney to face the Swans in opening round. “I actually thought we were going to play them six times and try to make as much money as we can,” Curnow said with a laugh. “I was talking to a few of the boys – I’m still getting used to changing up which boys I’m talking about, but I was chatting to some of my Blues mates like Weiters [Jacob Weitering] about the possibility of playing opening round, and it turns out the AFL did it in the end.” Curnow said he felt fresh and was enjoying getting stuck back into training after injuries ruined his last season with the Blues.

title: ‘Safety first’: Federation Square chief shut down gig to avoid crowd crush
text:
The last-minute cancellation of a free concert featuring Amyl and the Sniffers on Friday night was necessary to avoid a potentially catastrophic crowd crush after hundreds of people attempted to jump over barriers to the open-air venue, the head of Federation Square says.

On Saturday, Katrina Sedgwick, chief executive of Melbourne Arts Precinct Corporation – which manages Federation Square – defended the levels of security for the event and said sufficient planning had taken place beforehand. However, she conceded they may have to change how they stage events there in future.

Thousands of people filled Federation Square on Friday night before being informed the free concert had been cancelled. Credit: Simon Schuter

Thousands of music fans were devastated after the free concert was called off about 15 minutes before members of the Grammy-nominated Australian band were due to take the stage.

Sedgwick apologised on Saturday both to Amyl and the Sniffers – who expressed frustration on social media at the cancellation – and to the thousands of fans who missed out on seeing them perform.

title: Australian beef exempted from US tariffs as Trump cops cost-of-living backlash
text:
Washington: US President Donald Trump has exempted beef – including billions of dollars worth of Australian exports – from his sweeping tariff program as he responds to growing unrest from American consumers over the cost of living.

An executive order issued late Friday in the US (Saturday AEDT) confirmed beef was among several agricultural products that will no longer be subject to tariffs, including coffee and tea, cocoa, bananas, oranges, tomatoes and additional fertilisers.

The US is the biggest buyer of Australian beef. Credit: Bloomberg

That means the 10 per cent tariff applied to most Australian goods from April will no longer apply to beef – one of Australia’s leading exports to the US, with annual sales worth more than $4 billion.

The White House said given Trump had negotiated trade deals with a range of countries, he had determined it was “necessary and appropriate” to remove tariffs from certain products.

title: Drop punt it like Daicos: The AFL’s impact on NFL stars ahead of MCG showdown
text:
Los Angeles: When the Los Angeles Rams come to the MCG for the first regular-season NFL game in Australia, they could well be playing at the strange time of 10am, after a period of adjustment following a 14-hour flight.

If this sounds less than convenient – the morning start, if it happens, would be for the benefit of a vast TV audience in the US – the Rams players don’t care about how long they travel, about the unusual size of the MCG, or the potential for a weird starting time.

Ethan Evans shapes for a drop punt-style kick as the Los Angeles Rams take on the New Orleans Saints. Credit: Los Angeles Rams

“[It] makes no difference to me,” said star LA running back Kyren Williams in one of a series of interviews this week organised for Australian media by the Rams, who have struck a deal with the Victorian government that will see the Rams play an as-yet-unnamed opponent in the week of the AFL semi-finals.

“I’ll play wherever, wherever they tell us the ball’s going to be kicked off I’ll go play,” said Williams.

title: Sure, the Wallabies are tired. That’s not the only reason they’re struggling in the north
text:
The Wallabies have the chance to revive their tour against Ireland in Dublin this weekend, but the sense that a slow-motion car crash is unfolding in the north is not unfamiliar to the Wallabies faithful.

Since 2013, only two of the Wallabies’ end-of-season tours against Six Nations opponents have yielded more wins than losses. The first was in 2013, when new coach Ewen McKenzie guided the Wallabies to an impressive 4-1 record in what would turn out to be his only northern tour, and the second was in 2016, as Michael Cheika’s side went 3-2 in a tough tour that finished with losses to Ireland and England.

The Wallabies slumped to a demoralising defeat in Udine. Credit: Getty Images

Such successful tours were relatively commonplace in the first part of the new millennium. To provide an example of how expectations have changed, coach Robbie Deans was on the brink of being sacked after the Wallabies lost 33-6 to France in the first Test of the 2012 tour.

Deans’s side went on to beat England, Italy and Wales in the subsequent weeks.

title: The paradox of pace: What Australia and England have to do to win the first Ashes Test
text:
Perth, home to the WACA and the modern Optus Stadium, boasts a reputation built on sheer pace and bounce. The strip here is pure energy, where the ball flies with a velocity unmatched anywhere else. Instinct suggests that to conquer such an intimidating surface, a batter must meet fire with fire.

But here lies the paradox of pace: the hardest, quickest pitches in the world demand the slowest hands and the calmest mind. The harder a batter tries to hit the ball, the greater their chance of failure. To master the extreme speed, one must yield to it, allowing the wicket’s natural venom to do the work, converting pace into timing.

Paceman Mitchell Starc has had plenty of experience bowling at the WACA in Perth. Credit: Getty Images

The velocity generated in Perth is a potent psychological weapon. Cricketers fear facing a ball delivered above 140km/h, not because they worry about injury, but because they know they have too little time to react. This anxiety creates a profound vulnerability, turning a difficult challenge into a mental breakdown.

When facing express pace, a batter has less than half a second – closer to 0.4 seconds – to make a complex decision: whether they are playing or leaving, attacking or defending, and crucially, committing to the front or back foot. If a batter does not have a strong mental routine, the first thing that goes is their concentration.
